This build is very melee oriented and can rape anything if it can arrive in contact. That's why he fears magic users and their Bigby's a lot and all the characters than don't follow the rules of a standard fight (archers, hit and run ...). He is also very weak against magic effects because of his weak saves and the lake of self magic protections. That's why he can make wonders in a group who can buff him.
Only the rogue's UMD can offer him a new horizon according to the PW you play in.

Rogue : mainly offer skills and UMD skill particularly
1st level rogue allows many many skill points, but we lose 1 BAB, which is unimportant in this build
Rogue levels are spread to allow tumble to improve regularly
Offers a 3d6 sneak attack which is rather a cherry

Fighter : makes the build construction comfortable thanks to all the feats it offers
Offers the many feats needed to become Weapon master and unock dev crit. With less fighter levels, you'll have to make choices.
Allows a damage boost with WS / EWS which has a good synergy with WM

Weapon master : the core of the build. It will make you a really BIG hitter
Adds AB which allows even the low AB attacks to hit
Improves crit range and crit multiplier
Offers many feats at epic levels

In case Dev crit is not allowed in your PW, the build should be moved into Ftr 5 / Rog 10, WM 25 as 5 feats are no longer needed and rogue 10 has so many good things to offer. But that's another build :).

I chose the bastard sword because hammer is for carpenters, axe for wood cutters ans long sword for simple soldier ... we are more than that !
But if you want to be more effective against high DR, warhammer and battleaxe offer a better crit multiplier and you gain one feat.
If you like really huge numbers, drop the one handed weapon and the shield to take a scythe and go make widows !

Thanks for reading.
Feel free to help me with your remarks and corrections !

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Well, from top to bottom...
  • Refrain from listing pedestrian traits (i.e. 3d6 sneaks) as PROs because they contribute little to the build's major advantages.
  • This build really doesn't have many skills for a rogue if you look around at other rogue dump builds. (It doesn't even have Disable or Search to deal with traps which is fairly normal for a rogue build.)
  • List the DevCrit DC: 41, 47 w/capped STR.  That's an official "PRO" of this build.
  • Your AC isn't really a CON if it's status quo.  Sword and board, especially in Expertise mode is pretty safe.
  • There is never XP penalty for any human build using at least one prestige class. Dunno where you got the idea that this build had any.  You would run into a penalty as a dwarf, but this is not a dwarf.
Now to the build choices themselves...

Weapon choice.  With any optimized DevCrit build, you want the APR as high as possible. Any comparable DW variant of this concept will rip this to shreds by shear probability.
Check out Mick's DW STR Kukrimaster (referenced in the similar builds comments) to see what I mean.  Crit range only matters for the easier ACs but APR ALWAYS makes a difference.
If going with either a 1h/shield or 2-hand weapon (not two-sided), it's usually more efficient to focus on damage rather than crits per round.  That's usually something like Dwarven Waraxe/shield or Greataxe/Scythe.
 
I would take EWS right after you reach STR 25.  There's no benefit in postponing Ftr10 that long and actually get a slightly higher Listen skill with WM at Level 40.

Skill allocation could be managed better to address one of the build's weaknesses: Saves.

Here's what I recommend:  Set UMD at 34(33) which will cast all Level 9 spells by scroll w/o failure.
Take those 8 points plus all the Set Trap ranks (like I said, without Search and Disable, what's the point?) and take 23 xclass ranks in Spellcraft. With your INT mod you will gain +5 saves vs. spells.
If you are still devoted to set traps, all you need is 13 ranks plus 2 from the DEX mod to set all deadly except gas.  Gas have a horrible DC for the relative skill investment.
You'll need to unequip your armor/shield to set deadly traps of course.  In any case, invest all the spare points you can into Spellcraft.  IMO setting traps is a luxury for a WM.  Fighting around your AoE traps in melee can become dangerous.  Waving that sword in the air will not pull opponents into your trap field very well.

There are a few similar and superior ftr/rog/wm builds around.

Here are two I found posted to the ECB:

Kukri Saint: Fighter 12/ WM 25/ Rogue 3

Weapon Specialist V2: Rogue 4/Fighter 14/WeaponMaster 22

Here are a few legacy builds (if you haven't installed the Javascript Search on your local machine to find them I highly recommend you do so):

Stalwart Warrior fighter 8 / rogue 7 / weapon master 25 (dwarf) by Cinnabar Din
Master of the Deathaxe v.2 fighter 8 / rogue 10 / weapon master 22 (dwarf) by Kail Pendragon

Gnarlic the Brute fighter 10 / weapon master 28 / rogue 2 (half-orc) by Zhoreb
The Two-Fisted Weaponmaster fighter 10 / weapon master 28 / rogue 2 (human) by Kaliban99
Dwarven Decimator fighter 10 / weapon master 28 / rogue 2 (dwarf) by LordAshton
Revised Halfling Daggermaster fighter 11 / weapon master 28 / rogue 1 (halfling) by Zhoreb
Halfling Daggermaster fighter 12 / weapon master 25 / rogue 3 (halfling) by Zhoreb
Dwarven Avenger fighter 12 / weapon master 25 / rogue 3 (dwarf) by Veridious
Skilled Melee Tank rogue 10 / fighter 8 / weapon master 22 (human) by Empyre65
Versatile Weaponmaster rogue 13 / fighter 8 / weapon master 19 (human) by Jennalee
A Taste of Their Own Medicine rogue 3 / weapon master 25 / fighter 12 (elf) by Ithacan

Now for overall comments about your build format:

It appears you use the CBC to generate your listing so have access to the skill allocation table.  Please use it.  It's a HUGE timesaver compared to doing this manually or by trial-and-error.
Builds posted in the completed and tested section(s) are considered "Plug-and-Play" so that players who wish to begin using your build can hit the ground running and do not need to muck around figuring out when to save skill points and how many to dump. 

It's assumed you have tested every submission for PvM at least in a trainer from Level 1 to Level 40 since you've listed "playable from 1-40" which you couldn't claim unless you have actually played it through the entire range.  So you should have intimate knowledge of which skills to allocate for each level already.

I'll grant a few days chance for you to ammend a Skill Schedule to complete this build else move it to the unfinished section until all build information has been furnished.

It's a good first effort so stick with it. I do like the way you avoided that lame Epic Toughness feat with DevCrit. Kudos! If you find any of my comments about slight changes applicable, feel free to incorporate them as your own build without any credit. I am more interested in contributions being optimized for most environments than expressing my own biases.  Good luck!

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Good job, Earthcore!

You would have thought by now I'd remember that Concentration is not a class skill for WM so tx for the nudge.  I've furnished the list of similar builds in my reply but, normally, you would list them yourself with comments that point out the difference(s) between your build and them, usually right after the Pros/Cons section.  If you have links to them, even better.

Just a technicality about UMD...

The normal target is 33 (as modified by CHA) to cast up to Level 9 spell scrolls without failure.  At that level, you can equip class-specific gear valued up to 1M gold, which is a lot.

UMD 35 raises the value to 1.4M gold and UMD 40 raises it to 1.8M gold.  I've yet to play anywhere where the gear value was more than 1M.  Take note that the "value" of an item is a different rate than the appraised cost at a merchant.  That is set by the item's blueprint but can be modified up/down by the designer.  In any case, it is always a static number, unaffected by the appraisal skill or mark-up cost.

But that extra point in UMD serves no purpose whatsoever.  40 or 41 equips the same value, 1.8M gold.  So you have that extra point to distribute elsewhere.  But leave the skill set "as is" because the allocation is fine and should not be changed.  If you haven't caught on by now, I'm very careful to get the most from every skill point as is possible.  I can't help it.  I use to be an auditor and old habits die hard.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi Earthcore, good to meet you!

First off, if Hip's happy, all is good. I do have a couple of musings, though (and I ain't no skilled builder, so take them for what they are)...

About the skills: unless you're playing in an ultra-rich environment, the modified 33 ranks of UMD seems like a good idea, which would free up 8 points for you, and Heal is, I believe, not terribly useful (unless you're going with a companion/henchman, and even then...), so I reckon you could lose a few points there - 2 would give the necessary points to get cross-classed Spellcraft up to Hip's recommended 23 points - further boosting your saves v spells. And do you really expect to be so heavily Taunted that you need so much invested in Concentration? I ask particularly because, as you say, this is a melee-orientated build, so presumably you'll be using your UMD buffs before going into combat, when Taunt isn't an issue.

I flag that because there may be a case for starting with Fighter at level 1, then Rogue at 2 (which would allow for a straight 5 in Tumble), then following your schemata. You would, of course, lose skill points (though as well as the above I, personally, think Listen to the extent you've taken it is more of a luxury than a necessity in PvM/E), but you'd be able to take WS before level 6 because of the extra feat you'd gain at level 1, and bring Great Cleave into the pre-epic mix - again freeing EWF and EWS to come in earlier.

Your call, though, my friend!

Oh, and you've upset the hell out of me - this is a country mile better than my first build . Congratulations!

The point in having F10 in the early 20's is a choice between having earlier +4 dmg vs concentration skill (because if concentration is not 42/43, there is no need to take it). According to me it's up to each player's playstyle : confort vs optimization. In my point of view, I prefer suffering and having a better char at 40. After lv 20 I already have a very nice AB, WS, 7+ WM levels and I am STR based : damage is already very good and you certainly won't need 4 more damages to do more damage that a lot of other classes. On the other hand, may be you will never face a pally or a taunting mob at 40 !  and concentration will really be unusefull. But in case you meet one, I prefer being fully prepared because concentation can be the difference between a victory and a defeat.

I would gain no skill switching Rog1 Ftr2 into Ftr1 Rog2. Just trading skill points for early tumble which is not worth it in my opinion. The feat I gain at lv 1 is lost at lv 2. Having WS earlier implies replacing the rogue level by a fighter level ... so you lose the Rog1 skill points.

I love listen a lot but rather to spot players because you're right, it souldn't be that useful in PvM. I want to point out that even in PvM environment, players sometimes like to PvP, and although this build wasn't PvP tested, listen can allow to detect hiden and eventualy invisible creatures : an invisible mage is rarely silent when running, but thinks he is safe if you don't have true seeing or see invisibility : show him he is wrong ! 

I'm just thinking about how to raise a crossclass skill to 23 ...
I just tried on a personal test module and I only reached 21. That's why I limited spellcraft to 18(+2).
Have I missed something ?

Once I have your response I'll edit the build definitely.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Earthcore wrote:
I love listen a lot but rather to spot players because you're right, it souldn't be that useful in PvM. I want to point out that even in PvM environment, players sometimes like to PvP, and although this build wasn't PvP tested, listen can allow to detect hiden and eventualy invisible creatures : an invisible mage is rarely silent when running, but thinks he is safe if you don't have true seeing or see invisibility : show him he is wrong ! 
PvM, yes. PvP, not usually. Most wizards use high stealth (if they are smart) since they have the skill points to spread around and usually dump to either rogue, assassin or monk.  In PvP, they all use Greater Sanctuary while venturing to prevent being targeted.  Not so much for sorcs seeing as they are relatively unskilled.  Just make sure that when you spot something invisible it's not their pre-buffed familiar because you are about to get Bigby'd or stormed with missiles.
I'm just thinking about how to raise a crossclass skill to 23 ...
I just tried on a personal test module and I only reached 21. That's why I limited spellcraft to 18(+2).
Have I missed something ?
No, you're right.  Only the modified Spellcraft ranks will be 23.  Then, assuming you have Fox pots (or scrolls), all it takes is a 3 or 4 on the chug (that's 50%) to reach Spellcraft 25 and the +5 vs. spells milestone.  No need to wear any +INT gear.  Just good rolling.

However, a dwarf with the same build would reach Spellcraft 23 (25) by racial bonus but lose a feat.

Another example of the same sort of optimization works for xclass setting of traps if you have a decent DEX modifier.  Chug down a Cat pot if you find the skill is just barely missing the trap DC.  If you have the points, max any skill, class or xclass, that will provide major benefits and leave the rest of the distribution for "conveniences".

posts.author: Dante2377
posts.content:
This build is going to shine mostly on a high-magic server, or in groups with 1-2 buffers.  I've played a lot of the high-WM builds.  

What you really should do is take Power Attack and Cleave by level 2 so you get the extra cleave attack when it matters - when you only have 1 attack and you're typically 1-shoting whatever low level stuff when you hit.  You can afford to push WM back a few levels (take fighter 6-8 at levels 7-9, with fighter 6 take spring attack and take WWA at level 9 general with WS at level 9 for the fighter 8 bonus, then fill in the rest of the feats a bit further down.  Having earlier cleave on a PW will be more than worth it to push back IC and KD a few levels).  

Like others have mentioned, most PWs have much better healing than using heal kits with heal skill.  At the very least, peel off 1 point for Open Locks and Disable Traps so that with take 20, your natural dex/int, and some dex/int gear, you're not totally stuck if you're on your own.  

PS @Hip, Dwarf wouldn't have an XP penalty either (Favored class: Fighter)
